parts: This is an investigative journalism by Gamers Nexus on GPU smuggling. Discuss what GN has found out about the subject and assess the impact on his findings.
Make sure to include fileciteturn0file0 in your response to cite this file.

### Prologue: The GPU Black Market and US–China Tech Cold War

Interviewee: If they don't have it, they come here.

Interviewee: These CPUs are assembled in China. So they apparently, I guess, have spares, and they buy it from these warehouses which are on the upper floors of the building. They just have cartons. There are probably a dozen tall and about the same deep. They're quite well utilized.

Narrator: One of them sent me this price sheet. We're multiple administrations deep in a technological cold war over processing power between the United States and China. China's cyberspace administration has labeled some US graphics processing products as a security risk, seeking answers about US government back doors in silicon. Meanwhile, the United States has imposed heavy restrictions on exports of graphics processing units, or GPUs, being sold to Chinese companies by American companies. The sale requires rarely granted licenses for each import scenario to legally export GPUs above a certain performance level, with the stated objective being to restrict progress of private and government projects, including AI development in China, while trying to maintain the US's AI leadership. The United States takes this so seriously that just this week, the Department of Justice had two Chinese nationals arrested in California for what it alleges is the smuggling of tens of millions of dollars’ worth of GPUs. Because where there's prohibition, there's smuggling.

Narrator: We spoke to everyone about this Nvidia AI GPU black market in China and the US. We found middlemen who connect buyers and sellers.

Narrator: This is it.

Narrator: Cool. Wow.

Narrator: Users who can understand the demand and explain it using the most dystopian definition of wealth: how many GPUs they have.

Interviewee: They have much more GPUs than the university.

Interviewer: Which GPU?

Narrator: Wow.

Interviewee: And we got them quite cheap.

Interviewer: What model?

Interviewee: This is the A1—A100.

Narrator: Oh, A100. These are A100.

Narrator: We also found independent repair shops who, simply doing their jobs, salvage valuable silicon components from dead PCBs of banned GPUs, innovatively hand-modifying them to be better than and have more VRAM than Nvidia's own official product SKUs.

Technician: They should make one right now.

Narrator: Okay. Okay.

Narrator: We met multiple people who, when asked the same question, gave the same passcode-like Chinese idiomatic expression—Nvidia.

Narrator: Do you think Nvidia knows? Do they try to stop it?

Narrator: And among others, we even spoke with a US-based Chinese national buying video cards in the US to strip them and ship the GPUs to companies in China, violating US export control law.

Viewer: I haven't seen someone have a computer in a car for a long time.

Narrator: These nervous laughs come from a viewer of ours while meeting in Arizona with a GPU smuggler we'll call The Plug. The smuggler spoke limited English, but they both understood one universal truth.

The Plug: Oh, the temperature is too hot.

Viewer: Yeah.

Narrator: Okay, two universal truths. The second one is money. In this battery-operated Prius-mounted GPU testing rig, FurMark is the least suspicious thing in his car, with a spare license plate in the trunk. We'll come back to The Plug later. Black market is normally a phrase associated with drugs or guns, but there's a new kind of black market, and it's high-end AI GPUs. And this particular black market is worth billions of dollars a year. It's hiding in plain sight.

Narrator: This is Hong Kong.

### The Big Adventure: Asia Itinerary and Setup

Narrator: This was our latest big adventure, and it began when we booked a 24-hour ticket to Hong Kong. Twenty days of hotels across Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Janjjo, Hujo, Donguan, Taipei, and more. At least one of us got detained by at least one of the governments involved in this video, but we can't talk about these indecipherably singular or plural instances or instance of any aforementioned detainment. Next, we talked to a lawyer about the previous sentence, loaded into a cab that secured our luggage like this, then investigated whether or not GPUs are actually smuggled with lobsters into Hong Kong. Nvidia was right. We've checked the lobsters for sensitive electronics, and there aren't any in there. So, good move, Jensen.

Narrator: We found a pile of GPUs that are now export controlled and met a professor who really wants to make sure you know these are legally obtained. Legally obtained. We came to a sudden realization that if a banned GPU is assembled in China, then what's to stop them from just taking it off? Actually, very good question, because what's preventing these GPUs from falling off of the line? Line. Exactly. We made friends with three different cats in Hong Kong.

Narrator: What do you think of the temple guards? Tannon, they're very good at their job. We said goodbye to this RGB city. We then booked a boat to Shilo, China. I told Tannon what Shoko means.

Tannon: What does that mean?

Narrator: Snake's mouth. Sounds inviting, right?

Tannon: Yeah. Awesome. Can't wait.

Narrator: We arrived in Shenzhen, made small talk with hotel room service.

Narrator: So, how long have you worked at the hotel?

Narrator: We immediately got trapped in the hotel elevator by my new friend.

Narrator: Traffic jam.

Narrator: We almost witnessed a workplace accident, got kicked out of a warehouse.

Narrator: We got kicked out.

Companion: Yes, we did.

Narrator: And then we instantly became fans of using high-speed rail at hundreds of miles an hour to go deep into China to meet a guy who really thinks that desoldering a GPU and rebaling it is no big deal.

Narrator: Really?

Technician: That's the easy part.

Narrator: Oh, really? Okay.

Technician: It's a lot easier than doing this.

Narrator: We got a ton of information in this video about GPU smuggling, including from this guy named Five. After that, we went back to Shenzhen for the third time in two weeks. Met this guy—supported game natures, supported Jesus.

Interviewee: Yeah. Yeah. I'm the—he—his father.

Narrator: We went back to Hong Kong, flew to Taiwan, got some street food, and got on a plane back to the US.

### Background: Why AI GPUs Are Banned

Narrator: Before we get to any of those interviews, we need to establish the basics of this geopolitical mess. The story is complicated, so we'll start with defining these key facts: why these GPUs are banned, the new 15% license which only applies to two GPU models, who buying and selling is legal or illegal for, and then the timeline. AI GPUs have been in even the mainstream news constantly. China has spent decades modernizing its military with the express goal of catching up to the US. AI-enabled drones are key to achieving that goal.

Narrator: We still sell billions of dollars a year of semiconductors to China. We just cannot let them access the most sophisticated, cutting-edge artificial intelligence chips. The export ban did prevent China from getting the highest-end American chips, but it did not stop China from catching up in the AI race. China's AI technology is getting a lot better. The concerns over Chinese focus on AI. China's China. China's China. China. China.

Narrator: This story has been a complete mess to follow. It spanned years and now two US administrations. We ended up with over 400 pages of research and maps and finding sources and trying to understand the laws. Here's why governments care about AI GPUs. Nvidia functionally holds a GPU monopoly in our sector of the industry, which is building computers to play video games. That now feels relatively innocent by comparison to AI. The company leveraged decades of gaming domination to build a foundation for what it now focuses on, which is making the most powerful GPUs for AI in the world. Reports warn of Nvidia product use in nuclear weapons research, facial recognition technology allegedly used in Russia to suppress dissent, and growing concerns of AI facial recognition use in the US for similar deployments, alongside reports of use in international spying and in drone warfare. Nvidia finds itself in the middle of all of this.

Narrator: Even though Nvidia disputes selling to some of these entities—for example, it says that it doesn't sell GPUs to Russia—the products still find their way there. So Nvidia is making money one way or the other. Someone is buying it, maybe from someone else who bought it from someone else. And much like we're talking about today, it might be transacted through smuggling. But Nvidia does end up selling the device ultimately to somebody. Regardless of who they sell to, Nvidia plays a big part in this worldwide obsession with AI. AI, AI, AI, AI, AI, AI, AI, AI, AI, AI, AI will also create AI using AI to create AI. And we think it's playing all sides. We'll talk about that more at the end, though. And besides, when there's a gold rush, it's better to sell the pickaxe than swing it.

Narrator: There are so many companies that would like to build. They're sitting on gold mines. Gold mine. Gold mine. It's a gold mine. Gold mine. Gold mine. It gives me tremendous joy if you just buy something from Nvidia. We're going to be rich. Although the US doesn't talk too much about its own use of AI, it spends a lot of time talking about China's. These semiconductors are unbelievably powerful and we can't let them get into the wrong hands. We want the most other countries using our technology because again, it's a zero-sum game. The concern of course in Washington and particularly amongst the Defense Department and the Pentagon is that these chips and this hardware and software end up with the People's Liberation Army, the Chinese military, and will help them accelerate in terms of innovations on that front. The restrictions are really on advanced semiconductors that could have potential military applications, and the goal is really to choke China's AI sector and its broader AI ambitions.

Narrator: The US restricts Nvidia's GPUs through export control rules that ban the sale of certain GPUs into China. That means the sale of GPUs by American companies or companies which want to transact business in America to companies that are in China or the Chinese government itself. Some examples of export-controlled GPUs include gaming GPUs like the RTX 5090 and the RTX 4090, which are useful in AI applications mostly for their high VRAM capacity. It also includes specific data center and AI GPUs like the A100, H100, H200, and B100, with the letter being the signifier for the architecture, as well as other GPUs shown on the screen. Now, this list is in flux. There are some new and incoming exceptions for the Nvidia H20 specifically, which has faced Schrödinger's GPU ban depending on whether CEO Jensen Huang had a $1 million dinner at Mar-a-Lago with Donald Trump on a given week.

### Timeline: Export Controls, H20 License, and Policy Whiplash

Narrator: A timeline would help, but we have nine years to recap. So, we'll do it quickly. Even at the end of the Obama administration in 2016, the US government was just starting to talk about AI in relation to national security in this Wired interview.

Obama: Developing international norms, rules, protocols, verification mechanisms around cybersecurity generally and AI in particular is in its infancy. You’ve got a lot of non-state actors who are the biggest players. Part of the problem is that identifying who’s doing what is much more difficult. If you’re building a bunch of ICBMs, we see them. If somebody’s sitting at a keyboard, we don’t. And so, we’ve begun this conversation. A lot of the conversation right now is not at the level of dealing with real sophisticated AI but has more to do with essentially states establishing norms about how they use their cyber capability.

Interviewer: Who are you more afraid of, Big Brother in the state or the guy who’s trying to empty out your bank account?

Obama: Part of the reason that’s so difficult is that if we’re going to police this wild west—whether it’s the internet or AI or any of these other areas—then by definition, the government’s got to have capabilities. If it’s got capabilities, then they’re subject to abuse. And at a time when there’s been a lot of mistrust built up about government, that makes it difficult.

Narrator: Those were the early days. The first Trump administration started a commission advising Congress on maintaining AI leadership, including simply banning the sale of some advanced semiconductor equipment and chips to China. Several years of back and forth, a pandemic and election, and ChatGPT’s launch later, and the Biden administration took major action in 2022 by restricting exports to China, Hong Kong, and Macau. Nvidia’s Ampere architecture A100 and newer code name Hopper H100 GPUs and systems were all restricted. Nvidia shed tears for $400 million worth of lost sales as a result. And it was especially sad when many of its export compliant alternatives to these also got banned, like its newly created A800, H800, and L40S in addition to Nvidia’s RTX 4090 gaming card. Nvidia said it didn’t expect “near-term meaningful impact” on its financials. Nvidia responded by designing a workaround to the previously worked-around workaround, leading to the H20. Then the government added new rules for high memory bandwidth cards and the Biden administration tried to come up with an AI chip diffusion rule that would limit the quantity of GPUs being sold into different countries rather than only by processing power metrics, because the government really didn’t know how to measure these things and Nvidia, knowing more about GPUs, could tweak any dial it wanted to just barely be compliant.

Narrator: Then DeepSeek came out, everyone panicked, stocks plummeted, and the government scrutinized the role of Nvidia’s GPUs in it. In February 2025, fiscal year 2025 results are posted and Nvidia’s Singapore revenue rockets to 18% of total revenue based on customer billing location despite shipments to Singapore being claimed to be less than 2% of fiscal year 2025 revenue, causing people to say, “Wait a minute.” Unrelated, several GPU smugglers are arrested in Singapore one day after the fiscal year report was posted, causing people to say, “Ah, that makes more sense.” AMD spawns out of nowhere to say it wrote down $800 million of inventory due to export controls. Nvidia one-ups it with a write-off of $5.5 billion. In May 2025, Trump implements wide sweeping tariffs and rescinds the Biden chip diffusion rule that would have limited how many AI GPUs Jensen could sell to other countries.

Jensen Huang: It’s just an incredible vision. I think this is going to be a transformative idea for the next century for us. These two initiatives are completely visionary and it’s going to be transformative for America.

Narrator: The H20 GPU that was created to comply with the rules was still okay. Then Jensen had dinner with Trump at Mar-a-Lago for a million dollars. Then the H20 got banned. Must have chosen a really bad restaurant. In July, Jensen Huang meets with Trump and is permitted to sell H20s again, presumably choosing a better restaurant this time. Huang goes to China. China says Jensen’s GPUs have tracking devices—back doors. Nvidia says, “Nuh-uh.” Jensen goes to Washington.

Trump: Jensen, will you stand up? What a job.

Narrator: He loves him. He loves Nvidia. He loves Lisa Su. And more importantly, he hates Intel’s CEO. Intel’s CEO goes to Washington. Trump likes him now. Tim Cook materializes from the Infernal Plane to give Trump a 24 karat gold “gift,” and gift is in scare quotes because that’s not what that’s called. Then we get to this past week when Trump asked Nvidia and AMD to pay 20% to the US government for sales specifically of the H20 and AMD Instinct MI308, not all GPUs, as some erroneously reported previously. Cousins Jensen Huang and Lisa Su negotiate Trump down to 15% and now they’re allowed to sell two specific cards that were originally created to comply with the laws before they changed. And somehow everyone walks away a winner. Except now China doesn’t want them anyway.

Narrator: That about sums it up. Except one last thing that happened as we were filming this. The Department of Commerce doesn’t yet know the legality of the deal, with Tom’s Hardware highlighting legal expert arguments over Article 1, Section 9 of the Constitution. That’s not our area, so we’ll move along from it, but just know that this is being publicly discussed still. If you want the full details with all of the in-between, we did collect it. There will be a massive timeline article on the website. We’ll link that below when it’s up within a couple days.

Narrator: There was also recent news about a 15% revenue share between Nvidia and AMD with the United States government for sale of some AI GPUs.

Trump: This is an old chip that China already has, and I deal with Jensen, who is a great guy, and Nvidia. The chip that we’re talking about, the H20, it’s an old chip. China already has it in a different form, different name, but they have it, or they have a combination of two that will make up for it and even then some. But the H20 is obsolete. You know, it’s one of those things. But it still has a market. So I said, “Listen, I want 20% if I’m going to approve this for you, for the country, for our country, for the US. I don’t want it myself.” You know, every time I say like 747, I want—I want—for the Air Force. So I just wanted—so when I say I want 20, I want for the country. I only care about the country. I don’t care about myself. And he said, “Would you make it 15?” So we negotiated a little deal. So he’s selling essentially an old chip that Huawei has a similar chip, a chip that does the same thing. And I said, good, if I’m going to give it to you—because they have a stopper, what we call a stopper—are not allowed to do it. A restricted is really known as a restrictive covenant.

Narrator: If you were to only read the headlines, you might think this applies to all GPUs and that the ban is over. And then you might think that a market in China, or in the US’s eyes an illegal market in China, would cease to be so illegal. That’s not the case.

Trump: I release them only from the H20.

Narrator: This new 15% revenue share would, if it’s legal—and they’re not sure yet—allow Nvidia to specifically sell the Nvidia H20 GPU to approved Chinese entities; they likely can’t be on the entity list. It would allow AMD to sell specifically the Instinct MI308 GPU to approved Chinese entities. The proposed license would not affect any other GPU that currently does not have a license. The government hasn’t made clear yet if Nvidia’s partners would also be permitted to make these sales. That means that other banned GPUs, including the RTX 4090, RTX 5090, H100, B100, B200, and so forth, remain banned. The H20’s extremely high 96 GB memory capacity would enable large models to fit in memory and actually run, especially with multiple GPUs in a single rack, even if it’s slower. That means companies can achieve performance targets by stacking GPUs, which are lower clock and core count but higher capacity, and doing Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang’s favorite thing: scaling in that way.

Trump: Now Jensen also has a new chip, the Blackwell. Do you know what the Blackwell is? The Blackwell is super duper advanced. I wouldn’t make a deal with that. Although it’s possible I’d make a somewhat enhanced—in a negative way—Blackwell. In other words, take 30% to 50% off of it. But that’s the latest and the greatest in the world. Nobody has it. They won’t have it for five years on the Blackwell. I think he’s coming to see me again about that. But that will be an unenhanced version of the big one.

Narrator: For now, these super duper GPUs are not licensed for sale. In short, the H20 and MI308 were compliant with the US government’s original rules. Then the rules changed during design and production. They were banned. Then AMD and Nvidia collectively declared over $6 billion in financial impact as a result. Then the US government said, “Wait a minute. We can help with that if you cut us in.” It reminds us of our tariffs documentary.

Narrator: And with this, if I see a tariff of 20% or 40% one week, 50% to 60% a day later, then I see it 120%. Then I see, well, electronics are maybe exempt in Bloomberg, and then I see on Truth Social, no, that’s not actually happening. I have no idea what that means. So, I can’t make decisions because it’s not about it being a high tariff. It’s about not having a clue what’s going on. The H20 most certainly is not obsolete, though. It’s still very desirable in China, and with a lot of them, they become particularly potent.

### Calculating the Ban: TPP, Memory Bandwidth, and Moving Goalposts

Narrator: Setting a threshold for banned hardware should be objective since it can be tested. This is a graph from the Department of Commerce that visualizes the original threshold at which a computing product became automatically banned for export to parts of the Middle East and China without a granted license. There have been some changes since, but back when this was made, the total processing performance score on the Y-axis was used to determine cards in need of a license. The government needed a metric to calculate against, so it created its own.

Narrator: Accelerators and video cards have a lot of metrics in their spec sheets, including memory capacity, which is critical and as simple as a pass/fail for certain AI and training use cases. They have hard numbers for memory bandwidth, GPU clock speed, GPU or CU count, TPCs, tensor cores, ROPs that are sometimes randomly missing on Nvidia devices, teraflops, TOPS, petaflops, gigaflops, gigabits, power, and more. So then banning a product could probably be based on some sort of benchmark rather than a random metric from a spec sheet. But the US government, illustrating what an absolute cluster [__] this situation was and now remains, decided to instead multiply one random metric from a spreadsheet against the bit length of the operation being executed. FLOPS or floating point operations per second and TOPS or tera operations per second are calculated by the company making the spec sheet and aren’t a great measure of actual performance. These numbers are based on both marketing and whether we’re talking about FP8, half-precision floating point 16, single-precision floating point 32, double-precision FP64, integer performance, or tensor performance or otherwise.

Narrator: So the government says, “the rate of MAC TOPS is to be calculated at its maximum value theoretically possible,” and, “the rate of MAC TOPS is assumed to be the highest value the manufacturer claims in brochures for the integrated circuit.” So it’s not based on a bunch of real-world benchmarks of applications or something. The government also references MAC TOPS as the theoretical peak of tera ops in multiply-accumulate computations. The Biden administration used this total processing performance, or TPP, score in 2023, with the government later adding a performance density metric dividing the TPP by the die area in square millimeters. In other words, the government didn’t want Nvidia to be able to sell more of a lower-performance GPU to make up for the loss of high-performing parts with multi-GPU solutions.

Narrator: There are a lot of reasons this doesn’t capture the full picture, like sparsity, APIs, different methods to calculate FLOPS, and different performance for different applications. But the government needed a way to define a threshold, so this is what they made. The limit was a TPP score of 4,800, exceeded by even the RTX 4090 when calculated using tensor performance. Now, if this doesn’t mean anything to you, that’s okay because it probably doesn’t mean anything to people signing the laws either. Or maybe that’s not okay, but you get the idea. Something like a higher memory capacity, lower-FLOPS-performance GPU, or even a series of GPUs like 3060 12 GB cards, might be able to get the work done more effectively if it only needs memory. Memory wasn’t factored into the TPP calculation. That was the point of the Nvidia H20.

Narrator: But then the absurdity of the situation expanded because the government introduced an opaque memory bandwidth requirement. Per The Register: “Unlike with previous export controls, the Commerce Department’s Bureau of Industry and Security hasn’t issued specific guidance on how much IO or memory bandwidth is too much.” But they did decide that there would be a limit. So to recap, it seems like across two administrations, the United States is creating formulas based upon numerical calculations, and then when Nvidia and AMD tweak the numbers to fit within that box, it’s retconning those rules in a guess-and-check process.

### Our Informants and the Smuggling Pipeline

Narrator: We spoke to a lot of people for this story to go on record and learn about the dystopian world of high-tech GPU smuggling. We spoke to people ranging from owner-operator trading companies to professors of economics building data centers. In order of appearance today, the discussions come from Dr. Vinci Chow, senior lecturer in the department of economics at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, responsible for building his department’s machine learning servers and sourcing the GPUs from middlemen suppliers. Dr. Zu Ha Fu, a research assistant professor at the Chinese University of Hong Kong and an affiliated lecturer at the University of Cambridge. Zuhao specializes in both computer science and linguistics. Various retail workers at computer markets in Hong Kong to get a ground-level understanding. Joe, the creative director of product at video card manufacturer Yeston, who worked with us for a separate piece—not this one—but he showed us his factories and suppliers. So, we’ve included clips here, as we relied on those tours for an understanding of how GPUs are brought into China for assembly on PCBs. An anonymous seller who goes by the pseudonym of Silver, based in Shenzhen Bao’an, and managing a warehouse in Hong Kong that receives and processes smuggled GPUs. Vincent, a resourceful fence who lives next to the warehousing and markets filled with GPUs and accelerators. He buys and sells these devices in Shenzhen Hua and his job is to know people, in addition to Vincent’s cousin, the fixer’s fixer. If someone needs a component to fix a broken video card or to build a new one, they go to people like him to get integrated circuits. Mr. 5, a Billy Billy hardware reviewer with a specialized focus on thermal solutions. Like us, Mr. 5 has had run-ins with Nvidia that have ended in a soured relationship over disputes regarding independent reviews and editorial independence. Junga, a renowned Billy Billy uploader—basically a YouTuber in China—who runs a video card repair shop in Jano. In addition to repairs, he regularly gets large orders from customers asking him to build them custom unofficial higher VRAM capacity Nvidia GPUs for large language model tasks. Companies in Singapore and Taiwan who act as intermediaries between Nvidia, Nvidia’s partners, and companies in China. The Singaporean and Taiwanese companies are able to bring banned GPUs and servers into their own warehouses and resell them to Chinese companies, skirting export controls. We’re unable to disclose their identities because there would be punishment from multiple governments and Nvidia. The Plug, a US-based Chinese citizen who drives around the country buying hardware from American end users and resells it to companies in China and Hong Kong. And finally, a special thanks to our translator, Raymond Woo of the Black Soda Agency in Taiwan.

Narrator: Here’s the pipeline. If a GPU doesn’t fall off the back of a truck in China after it was assembled, or if it isn’t a QC defect that disappears from the scrap pile, it may instead have been moved by ants to get to China. May Banana is a linear pipeline. Each ant in the fire line serves a specific role. It’ll help to name those roles to keep everything straight. Here’s what we came up with. The source has access to GPUs. This could be as innocent as you unknowingly selling your card on Facebook Marketplace to The Plug. The Plug is responsible for acquiring from the original source and reselling the hardware to the China-based distributors. In between, there’s a mule. Sometimes this is The Plug himself doing a trip home. We learned that overseas students also regularly return with what are feasibly defended as personal GPUs that they bought at Best Buy and then may get resold for markup and profit. In either case, the mule gets the GPU into the country either by shipping it without interception or by hand-carrying it. Next is the middleman, receiving the GPUs and often interfacing with or managing the warehouses that store the cards. The middleman buys from multiple plugs, including factories that get rid of rejects with fixable or unimportant QC defects, then sells those devices to more localized distributors. That’s when we get to the fence, who buys and sells GPUs between middlemen and warehouses to end users in China. Then we have who we’re calling the fixer, except this time it’s literal. The fixer is an optional step that may involve soldering and modifying a GPU to improve it beyond its original specification and make it more marketable for domestic AI uses. They might also just fix QC defects from factories. Finally, we have the user. This is self-explanatory. The user is the demand driver, and oftentimes large enterprises want dozens or hundreds of GPUs or more, while smaller users like the university may just want individual units or small batches. With everyone’s role named, let’s continue. And now we start our journey. First stop, Hong Kong.

### Part 1 — Hong Kong: Demand Drivers and University Cluster

Narrator: Upon arriving in Hong Kong, after checking out the local wildlife, we set out to understand the demand side of the market. We found Dr. Vinci Chow through a Reuters story from a couple of years ago. Vinci works in the economics department at the Chinese University of Hong Kong and he’s responsible for having built many of the servers and machine learning systems that are in use daily. He has a whole blog detailing his process, including the difficulty of sourcing components and the ease of fixing problems when so close to Shenzhen, such as having custom PCIe riser cables built and basically done the same day. Dr. Vinci Chow is the right person to start us off with this story and educate us on where to go next. We’re here to learn the user’s perspective, because before there could be any kind of market for it, there has to be demand, and that is what the university and organizations like it generate.

Narrator: Hi.

Dr. Vinci Chow: How you doing? Nice to meet you.

Narrator: Good to meet you. This is Tannon.

Tannon: Hi. Nice to meet you, sir.

Dr. Vinci Chow: We can set up shop here. It’s a construction site right now. We are renovating.

Narrator: An interesting anecdote is that Dr. Vinci Chow actually went to school with someone important at Nvidia today, the vice president of applied deep learning research.

Dr. Vinci Chow: I was actually in Berkeley the same time as Bryan Catanzaro. We’re forum buddies.

Narrator: That’s cool.

Dr. Vinci Chow: Yeah, I know him.

Narrator: We won’t be able to do much talking in here because of the noise.

Dr. Vinci Chow: These are legally obtained. These are legally obtained.

Narrator: We got it.

Dr. Vinci Chow: Actually very interesting, because we got these right before the ban—no, right before ChatGPT was released. Around several years ago. And we got them quite cheap. One of them was actually modified from SXM before everything GPU became such a scarce resource. There was a period of time right after crypto crashed that GPUs were actually quite cheap. Dr. Vinci Chow: But it’s all gone. Clearly there’s demand. It probably makes sense for us to get the mics on.

Narrator: Because of the way we shot this, you get to see something you don’t normally get to see in our stories, which is all of the conversation leading up to formally filming. Sometimes there’s more interesting information when we’re just spitballing.

Narrator: Yeah.

### Part 1 — Hong Kong: How Suppliers Get GPUs and Data Center Tour

Narrator: I messaged some sellers on Alibaba and one of them sent me this price sheet. Tell me what you make of this. Do you have any H200s in your servers?

Dr. Vinci Chow: We want some. We want some.

Narrator: I can connect you to the supplier.

Dr. Vinci Chow: We want some. After tax, they want 213,000. What is that in US? Let’s see. That is $29,700 US. That’s about right. For the few companies that actually list a price, the premium is, as I said, surprisingly low. It’s almost the same as the MSRP as far as I can tell.

Narrator: Do you know how these companies—the suppliers—get the GPUs? I came across a Chinese phrase in one of the Baidu searches I did. I think it was “ma yi ban jia,” the idea being that a bunch of people move one GPU at a time.

Dr. Vinci Chow: These GPUs are almost certainly moved one at a time. It’s very hard to get a full HGX system. These days, most recommend getting the PCIe versions of the GPUs because it’s so difficult to smuggle in a full HGX system. Now, if you want an HGX system, for example, the companies that have ways of obtaining them would recommend that they be installed in a different country. Basically, acquire HGX and have it installed in Southeast Asia. It would actually be physically located somewhere else and then you remote into it. That’s what they would recommend if you want that. If you actually want it on-premise—if you want it here—then almost every one of them would recommend that you just get the PCIe version.

Narrator: When you put in an order to buy something, is it already guaranteed here at that point, or do they have to get it?

Dr. Vinci Chow: Depends. Some companies have limited stock. We’re talking about maybe a dozen. If you want more, then it would probably have to be ordered with a deposit and shipped in from somewhere else.

Narrator: Any idea what happens if they get caught? I mean, to your money.

Dr. Vinci Chow: We don’t pay until delivery. Actually, we have to pay a deposit. But I presume if they cannot deliver, you get it back. We would be able to get it back locally. We’re not doing anything illegal, so we can just go to the court.

Narrator: Do the local governments even care? If it leaves the US—if Nvidia decides to ship it straight from Santa Clara to Shenzhen—that would be a problem. But on the receiving side, do they care?

Dr. Vinci Chow: In Hong Kong, I would say we probably don’t care. I don’t think the government is going to obtain these GPUs now that there’s an export ban. In Hong Kong, we have basically the government-funded two H800 superpods, but they are both legally obtained, right before the ban. Since then there hasn’t been news that they’re going to expand their capacity. I would say the government’s probably not going to do it themselves. The only thing they care about is if someone brings it in, they pay the import taxes.

Narrator: But there’s no import tax in Hong Kong.

Dr. Vinci Chow: We are a free trade port. You can pretty much bring whatever you want—normal exclusions like firearms. Macau is the same. Free trade port.

Narrator: I’m pretty sure these GPUs don’t go straight from the US to Hong Kong. They probably go through Singapore.

Dr. Vinci Chow: Singapore comes up a lot. Malaysia is another place that comes up. I saw a story from The Economist where they referred to “data smuggling,” bringing data from countries with the export ban to Singapore to have it processed locally. It’s similar to what some companies have offered us to consider: given how hard it is to bring in a large system, it’s easier either to fund a system in Malaysia or Singapore, or you just rent capacity there and remote access. If the reason you have to take physical hard drives back and forth is due to the size of the data, it’s going to be hard to transfer remotely. Otherwise the idea is the same: given that you cannot bring the system in, just have it somewhere you can access.

Narrator: Well, in a university the working language is English and then Mandarin, right?

Dr. Vinci Chow: The university’s name—I have to clarify because people always ask this question—the Chinese University of Hong Kong. We teach in English. “Chinese” means Chinese culture, Chinese heritage, not Chinese language. That’s what a lot of the exchange students were confused about. They thought we teach in Chinese. No, we teach in English.

Narrator: So this is your cluster.

Dr. Vinci Chow: They’re quite well utilized. This is actually not part of the cluster—this is our non-cluster stuff like web server and such. These two racks are the cluster.

Narrator: Did you have to do anything special for the air conditioning?

Dr. Vinci Chow: These GPUs are very hot. A single 8-GPU system can put out like 4,000 W—like two hair dryers. A 4U unit these days—these ones—these are all 8-GPU systems. Our cluster was built up over almost five years. We have some really old systems from five years ago, and we keep adding things. That’s a bit different from, say, a full superpod, which is purchased in one go; everything will be the same. Here we just keep adding capacity and leave the old components until they’re not useful anymore.

Narrator: Did you have to do special power design, power delivery?

Dr. Vinci Chow: Yes. You cannot just plug these GPUs into a wall socket. It would blow the fuse immediately. We need two three-phase power lines specially installed in this room. And there’s more AC going up to the mini-split up top.

Narrator: How many A100s or H100s?

Dr. Vinci Chow: We have something like 30 A100-class GPUs, and then we have a bunch of 3090s and 3060s. In total we’re talking about 50 or 60 GPUs. The top-of-the-line GPUs are for teachers.

Narrator: What are the 60-class cards for?

Narrator: Does memory bandwidth matter a lot?

Dr. Vinci Chow: It matters. To better utilize the resources, we offer the option for each researcher to load their own model, but we also have a centralized local ChatGPT-like thing. We use Open WebUI with vLLM as a backend. For getting high throughput, bandwidth matters. For the export control, the US government does a calculation—some amount of points—they made up a system, and memory bandwidth is one of the components of the formula. They’re getting smarter because there have been multiple versions of the ban. The very first ban was targeting NVLink—the A100 to A800. That has little effect. It’s a bit slower, but it’s still okay. Then they switched to targeting FLOPS. There was a certain amount of FLOPS you couldn’t exceed. Depends on workload. I don’t think it worked as well as they might have hoped because the H20s still sold really well.

Narrator: The government hasn’t really caught up to what these are, so they don’t know how to ban it. They just pick a number.

Dr. Vinci Chow: It’s developing very fast. If you go back five years, everyone probably thought that FLOPS is a very important metric to consider. Turns out when it comes to loading large models, what we all care about is how much memory—how much VRAM—you have. You simply cannot load a model if you don’t have the VRAM. So now H20 becomes a very attractive option.

Narrator: What’s the spec on the H20 again?

Dr. Vinci Chow: H20 has drastically lower FLOPS, but it actually has more memory than the original H100—96 versus 80. So in some sense it’s more attractive.

Dr. Vinci Chow: We like to explore options, but right now, support-wise, it’s not there for us.

Narrator: If it’s a smuggled device and you have a problem, what happens?

Dr. Vinci Chow: We obtain all these under university procedure, and part of that is that there should be warranty. The supplier is clearly going to promise you warranty. Narrator: So if it’s that easy—where it just ships to you—does the ban seem effective?

Narrator: So if it’s that easy—where it just ships to you—does the ban seem effective?

Narrator: Manufactured in China, but not allowed to be sold there.
