Translator (Raymond): He can do the 24 to 48 GB right now.

Narrator: I think we’re going to make a 48 GB 4090 right now. This is a 24 GB 4090 that’s been through a lot of repair steps. Up here they track the repair history on the card in order. It’s been through six repair steps. The board’s been through a lot. It originally didn’t work at all, then had a memory problem, then other problems in between. Now it’s actually working. It’s functioning now and you can see it even turns on. It’s a 4090 and it’s got all 24 GB detected. But because this board has been through so much trauma from repairs, it’s better to harvest the expensive components and put them on a new board so they don’t have to worry about it failing again in the future from something else. The next step is going to be to put the extra memory on it to go to 48 GB.

Narrator: What’s the success rate of the swap?

Translator (Raymond): Ninety-nine percent. There’s still like a one percent chance of failure.

Narrator: That’s really good. They’re protecting from static with the cover on the PCIe slot. Now we’re going into the lab.

Narrator: Because Nvidia doesn’t make a 48 GB 4090, the repair shop has to source its own PCB. It needs something that has enough pads for all the memory modules they’re adding to it. They work with a third-party supplier that builds a PCB, uses an SMT line to place all the VRM components, and has the extra wiring, circuitry, and pads to support 48 GB of memory. That’s what you’re looking at here. It’s a custom board just for this.

Narrator: First is disassembly. He’s going to take apart the old card. Sometimes people buy 10 or 20 at a time and these go into servers for AI—running models or whatever they’re doing.

Narrator: Does Nvidia care? This isn’t an official SKU.

Translator (Raymond): They can’t do anything anyway. It’s aftermarket—like souping up your car. Sometimes Nvidia blocks stuff in firmware or BIOS to try and block a modification.

Narrator: How long does this step normally take?

Narrator: He’s heating the GPU to about 260°C—really similar to what we saw with EVGA—just blasting the GPU with heat. It takes about five minutes and then he’ll be able to pull the GPU off. Now he’s pulling the GPU. It happens really fast. He puts it on a metal stand.

Narrator: Now they’re using a board heater. There’s a temperature reading on the front—currently at 133°C—then up to 320°C. The hot air station is at 396°C. He’s going to heat the board and then use the hot air station to heat pinpointed memory modules and remove them without risking damage to other components on the board. They keep the original memory modules. He’ll pull these and keep them, and they also have new modules they bought—from Tao, basically—and they’ll add those to the board so they can double the memory capacity.

Narrator: Now they’re working the reballing process. There’s a template for the solder balls. He’s cleaning with rubbing alcohol, pours solder balls into the stencil, does eight at a time, and bakes the new solder balls onto the memory modules, which they can then attach to the PCB. He’s already applied flux and is wetting the solder balls. Now he’s using a wick—a solder wick—to pull off excess solder and smooth the surface.

Narrator: What do 48 GB cards normally sell for?

Translator (Raymond): Twenty thousand RMB—about $2,800 US.

Narrator: Now they’re adding heat again—hot air at about 390°C—holding the memory while pressing it into the hot plate, which is at 195°C. He can only do eight at a time, so he’ll repeat the process.

Narrator: Is it hard to get 4090s or 5090s for him?

Translator (Raymond): Customers bring them. He doesn’t actually buy—he just repairs.

Narrator: It’s crazy how in the US there are a couple shops that can do repairs, but they don’t really do this level of repair. I don’t know of a single shop in the US that does the memory modding.

Translator (Raymond): Labor cost is a huge issue in the US. For him, it’s worth it. For the customers, it’s worth it. The service cost here is not as high.

Narrator: Next stage: at this point they’ve reballed all of the memory and the GPU. Now he’s cleaning the surface to prep it to mount to a new PCB. We saw the new PCB earlier—it’s a brand-new custom PCB they just ordered from Tao. He’s adding flux now. As Lewis Rossman says, you can never have enough flux.

Narrator: There’s a custom template for the GPU just like for the memory. He applies that to the surface, uses a tray to catch the excess, and sifts it. He wipes off the extra and carefully removes the template while leaving the balls in place, held by the flux. This is a jig to hold the GPU in place.

Narrator: Now the GPU is on there. We’re at the final stage. This whole process is about two hours. Now we’re doing the opposite of earlier—adding the GPU back. He’s very carefully positioning the GPU to precisely align the BGA with the solder balls. He starts to reach steady state on temperature—a couple hundred degrees. There’s a ton of bubbling at the edges, but they’re baking the GPU back on. At this point, the PCB has been swapped. The PCB already had all the VRM components and the I/O populated—12VHPWR high power. They’ve added new memory to the front and the back—one side reused, one side brand new—and the GPU has been pulled and swapped and is now being remounted. They’re telling us this is a 99% chance of success.

Narrator: He’s going to cool it off with a fan. Do they reuse the same cooler that they took off the old board, or do they need a new cooler?

Translator (Raymond): They reuse. There’s only one choice for the cooler. No options.

Narrator: Moment of truth. He’s just going to hold the heatsink on and see if it powers on. It’s got a green LED, the display debug up top. We’ve got display up top, so it is functional. Now it’s just a question if everything detects.

Translator (Raymond): We’re lucky. Usually it doesn’t turn on the first time in a while. They know we have a train to catch.

Narrator: Do the customers who buy these mostly put them in servers?

Translator (Raymond): If the customer buys multiple units, then it’s probably for servers. That’s why the blower fan would be better—they pack them in so tight. But there’s only one cooler—they don’t really have a choice.

Narrator: Next step: one of the last steps in the process. Since it booted and worked, they’re pulling the protective film from the thermal pads. There’s a pre-applied paste—it looks like it was silk-screened on there.

Narrator: Looks like it works. Within two hours, start to finish, we have a working 4090 48 GB. At the beginning of this process, the card was working, but it had been through so many repairs that it was very likely it’d break again at some point from something they couldn’t really predict. From a waste standpoint, it’s way better to figure out a way to save that card because the PCB is kind of the least valuable thing and is also the least precious of the resources. Being able to save the silicon that’s in the memory and in the actual GPU itself—that has a lot of value, especially in China where they just don’t have as much supply. Even though the supply looks pretty damn good from what we saw, it’s still intentionally restricted. Purely from the perspective of the people living there, not only is this better than what Nvidia shipped to begin with and really not that far off in price when it was at its most scalped, it’s also a good way to keep the silicon in circulation even as things like MOSFETs, capacitors, or PCBs die. The silicon tends to be pretty resilient and it doesn’t really die that often on GPUs.

Narrator: What this tells us is that this is maybe an alternative method to getting more GPUs into supply. If they take the broken boards and then put functional silicon back into circulation, it’s a certain level of ingenuity, and there aren’t many places that are set up to handle it. Brother John’s shop is impressive. After finishing at the repair shop, we rushed over to the high-speed rail, spent six hours traveling back to Shenzhen Bay, adding another thousand miles or so to our travel log here, and then we took a car over to visit the next stop.

### Part 7 — Factory: How GPUs Are Assembled and Disappear

Narrator: After finishing at the repair shop, we rushed over to the high-speed rail, spent six hours traveling back to Shenzhen Bay, adding another thousand miles or so to our travel log here, and then we took a car over to visit this guy. He calls himself the Chinese Eminem. Eminem in China. So, this is Joe. He works as a creative director of product at the video card manufacturer Yeston, most famous for their waifu video cards. You know the ones.

Joe: Yeah. Yeah. I’m the—he—his father.

Narrator: She’s father.

Joe: She’s father. Yes. She’s father.

Narrator: Anything else you want to talk about on camera?

Joe: I think we got it all. Game natures.

Narrator: I also have the same nickname.

Joe: Which one? Yes. Tough guy. Tough guy. All for I will put your head on the ground.

Narrator: Now, Joe and Yeston were not officially contributing to the black market side of the research here, just to be clear to their own partners. Instead, they showed us around their factory. This will be a separate upload later with an actual factory tour with them showing how the waifus are made. But in this particular video, there were a few interesting things we learned that fit here pretty well. The big takeaway from the factories is that they receive their GPU supply, of course, from their partners—that would be AMD, Intel, or Nvidia—and the memory is often packaged with it. But for the most part, everything else that they use, unless they’re buying reference PCBs, comes from whatever sources they want to find for their supply.

Narrator: We were also informed that there’s very little oversight in terms of the management of the rejects at these places. They can file for refunds if, for example, a chip is bad. But if they screw up a board in their own process—like the SMT line is miscalibrated and optical inspection doesn’t catch the error and they place a MOSFET on backwards and blow something up—then it’s going to be on them to deal with the defect. This type of thing basically never happens. All of this stuff is highly automated. The point of pointing it out, though, is that for at least the gaming-class cards, which the 5090 more or less is one of, there’s enough volume and Nvidia’s hands-off enough that it would be pretty easy to make these disappear. The biggest reason for this is that there are partners for the 5090s. It’s not like a card that only Nvidia makes, such as the RTX Pro 6000 in the Blackwell edition. And since there are partners, Nvidia is only tracking when they sell them the GPUs. They don’t necessarily keep tabs on where those get distributed once they’re done being manufactured. So, for this reason, if a factory wants to just sell it domestically in China and they think they can get away with it without being added to the entity list, which would very likely kill their business with Nvidia, then they can go ahead and sell them domestically. That might be how some of these trading companies get a hold of them. It’s an easier way to make them disappear than through channels that are more publicly visible from Nvidia and government. Now, Yeston doesn’t make 5090s, but the processes they taught us about illustrate how that could happen.

Narrator: As for the server-grade solutions, there are manufacturers for those that are pretty tightly controlled. Basically, the silicon is made in Taiwan. It’s shipped to wherever it’s going to be assembled. Almost all of the other components are sourced in China, and as a result, it’s easiest to keep the whole supply chain there, including the assembly. The assembly involves the same stuff you’re seeing for the lower-end cards and the AMD solutions we’re looking at from this factory line. They use surface-mount technology, or SMT lines, with conveyed inflow of PCBs, reels upon reels of components that are placed smallest to largest, with the most valuable typically at the very end—that would be the GPU—and then manual placement for heat sinks. There is often manual assembly even for Nvidia’s high-end stuff. Although we can’t show you that here, we have seen it being made. That’s in different factories.

Narrator: At the end of the process, it’s possible they find a defect. Again, Dr. Vinci Chow had one where he has a broken link on his board. There’s a good chance that stayed in China and never left. If it was reported as a defect to Nvidia, then it may have effectively just been written off and considered trash. But after seeing how a highly skilled group like Brother John’s repair shop can repurpose all those components that are still good, you can see how there would be value in figuring out a way to make that board disappear, even if it’s supposed to be in the trash. This comes back to Nvidia’s turning a blind eye because they’d eventually notice it from the serial number popping up somewhere, but maybe they choose not to. And besides, once someone has it—especially in China—there’s not a ton they can do anyway. That’s a look inside the manufacturing process, which we felt was an important piece to this story.

### Part 8 — Taiwan and Singapore: Intermediaries and Pass-Throughs

Narrator: My favorite place to go in the world, Taipei, Taiwan. Most of our stay in Taiwan was for other stories. However, we did accidentally unturn one stone with something interesting under it. We can’t show any B-roll for this because we do protect sources, so we’re just showing some other footage instead. A B2B company in Taiwan noted to us that it’s commissioned by Chinese companies to import servers for pre-testing and pre-assembly and setup steps. When we asked what the GPUs were that the servers ran, having just done all the rest of this, we realized that all of the hardware is export controlled. Once the B2B agency completes its testing, it ships the system out to the original buyer. Basically, they act as an intermediary to buy the machine, mark it up, and reship it to the original purchaser, maybe with actual testing. We also spoke with a company that conducts business in Singapore. The company informed us that they are also aware of similar pass-throughs for so-called testing or data services.

### Part 9 — The Smuggler: The Plug’s U.S. Operation

Narrator: Our last link in this chain is actually the first—the smugglers—bringing it full circle. And the smugglers themselves also put us back in the United States. We didn’t think we’d be able to find someone doing the dirty work here, but in the final hours, a viewer had a lead. This led to about a 12- or 16-hour production delay as we were wrapping the project, but as far as we’re aware, this is the first content piece that actually features someone doing the highest-risk dirty work. Everyone else we spoke to is in China. They’re safe from US retaliation. But large-scale smugglers get arrested, fined millions of dollars, and can spend years in prison if they were really serious.

Narrator: A viewer contacted us to say that he’d connected with a traveling GPU buyer. The story went that this guy drives around buying specifically RTX 4090s. He doesn’t care about anything else, including 5090s, because those don’t sell as well to China. 4090s are ideal, he told us, because they can be modified into cost-effective 48 GB models like we saw at Brother John’s shop. The smuggler was extremely open with us in text messages written only in Chinese, but wasn’t open to us flying out to him. He did allow us to share this video of his car, though. The Plug, as we call him, has an ATX test bench, motherboard, simple downdraft cooler, and a gigantic battery in the trunk of his Prius. He also has at least one spare license plate in the trunk in addition to the one on the back of his car. We’re not sure why, but better not to ask.

Narrator: People like The Plug post on Facebook Marketplace and other common online reseller forums looking to buy GPUs, just like anyone else in your city would. The Plug offers $2,000 flat per 4090. It doesn’t matter which model it is. It’s not a bad price. He told us that he then finds ways to get them into China. He recently was scammed out of $5,500 of payments owed by a Hong Kong buyer, and that buyer resells in Hong Kong. He’s been considering hand-carrying the devices in luggage instead. Margin is slim. He makes just under $300 US per GPU profit, but that’s before counting gas, potential hotels as he travels, and time. Our understanding is that some in his shoes will strip the GPU cooler off and ship just the PCB back to China, increasing their margin. Coolers are available in abundance where they’re made, so it can be cheaper to do this than pay for the weight and the size. He sometimes buys entire computers just to take the 4090s out, as that’s what the bounty’s on. He then sells the remaining system back to whoever will buy it. He told us that 5090 prices in China are falling so fast due to oversupply, ironically, that he’d lose money reselling it to China and would do better flipping it to Americans.

Narrator: The Plug isn’t rich. He seems to be doing okay, but it’s not the type of wealth you might expect for taking such risk. We can’t overstate how important it was to get this piece of the story, as this allowed us to fully complete the chain. And a huge thanks to our anonymous viewer who set that up. Many of the sources we met in Asia during this trip told us they simply don’t know how the GPUs actually get in. Now we know people doing this on a small scale, like The Plug, are unlikely to be caught. But operations transacting millions of dollars’ worth of GPUs would have a harder time getting them out undetected. And that brings us to the end of our travels, but not the end of this piece. We have two more entities to look at, and that’s Nvidia and the US government.

### Legality: Who Can Buy and Sell, and Where

Narrator: The legality is simple. This is our understanding of it. There’s no restriction on purchasers, only on sellers the US has control over. Even Americans buying GPUs in China are not violating any laws. It is not restricted. So, we’ll start with selling. The simplest answer to who the sale of GPUs is restricted for is anybody who doesn’t have a specific export license and who would be governed by US law, and Nvidia can’t just bypass it by shipping from a different country instead. It has to do with the sale, not with the shipment location. That includes entities buying from US companies, like European companies, who would be under guidance from both Nvidia and, if they do business with the US, its government. It’s also illegal for anybody in the United States, citizen or not, to sell these GPUs to China, Hong Kong, Macau, or companies in those locations if the seller does not have a re-export license. It is not illegal for a person of any nationality in America to sell a GPU to any non-restricted entity. As for buying, there’s absolutely nothing illegal about for us over here to buy these GPUs, but it’s also not illegal to sell them in China for a Chinese company. The Chinese government doesn’t generally enforce American export laws. Other nations cooperating with the United States might, such as recent arrests in Singapore. But once the GPU is in China, the people in possession of it likely don’t care—buyer or seller, or someone who does both, like GPU dealer Vincent.

Narrator: The only control over Chinese companies that the US has is the entity list, which would hurt their business prospects with American companies, but only if they care about that. Chinese GPU middleman Sutan Halei in Tianjin landed on the entity list for transacting banned GPUs and being found out. Sutan Halei purchases GPUs from anyone who can get them into China, and then they bid on domestic projects like data center buildouts. The entity list was used to restrict, for example, Deepcool previously, resulting in their American partners ceasing business with them for fear of frozen assets, audits, or collateral bans. So this hurts companies like Deepcool that want to operate in the US, and it even shut down their California office. But for Sutan Halei, they mostly want to do business with other Chinese companies, and so it would have limited impact unless they wanted to expand to do business with Americans. Beyond the entity list, the US really has no control over what happens inside Chinese borders. That means the only point at which a GPU could feasibly be intercepted and a person arrested would be operating in the US or in transit to intermediary countries such as Singapore, which may have their own export laws. The people buying and selling them within China are not breaking any of their own government’s laws, though. And so, we come back to Nvidia.

### Corruption: Nvidia, Governments, and the Fake News Playbook

Narrator: At every turn, it really looks like Nvidia is playing all sides. If there’s enough money to be made, anybody is Nvidia’s friend. We think the story of AI GPUs has become a story of corruption between governments and the wealthiest company on Earth.

Narrator: On April 30th, Amazon-backed AI startup Anthropic called on the US government to increase export control restrictions to China. As part of this blog post, Anthropic said the government needs to improve its export enforcement to reduce smuggling. The company cited examples of chips being smuggled with “prosthetic baby bumps” and “live lobsters.” This upset Nvidia because Nvidia doesn’t like restrictions to making money. So Nvidia shot back, seemingly taking a page out of Trump’s playbook. Nvidia essentially called this fake news: “American firms should focus on innovation and rise to the challenge rather than tell tall tales that large, heavy, and sensitive electronics are somehow smuggled in ‘bumps’ or ‘alongside live lobsters.’”

Narrator: Except Anthropic isn’t telling tall tales. It’s right. A 2022 video that we uncovered showed a security check at Zhuhai, a port in Guangdong not far from Shenzhen, wherein a woman with a prosthetic baby bump was shown to have been carrying CPUs and iPhones instead. The report made it to customs.gov.cn, stating that she arrived from Macau, a common go-between similar to Hong Kong. This story got international attention in technical media, and we reject the possibility that Nvidia wasn’t aware of it. We found the official Chinese government posting about smuggling from Macau. Imports to most of China are taxed, and so tax evasion coupled with smuggling will increase margin on the electronics rather than sharing it with one of the two governments. If you’re already breaking a US law, it seems some just go for a hat-trick and increase the profits.

Narrator: As for the lobsters, that’s real, too. We unearthed this official Hong Kong customs website detailing a white van busted driving on the Zhuhai–Macau bridge filled with 280 kg of undeclared live lobsters and, yes, 70 smuggled GPUs, complete with photo evidence. The Hong Kong customs itself calls this “smuggling” and notes a maximum sentence of seven years. Nvidia’s response to call these tall tales is not only defensive but serves to gaslight and grossly mislead, we think, and is tantamount to lying for sake of downplaying reality for its own benefit. But then this is a common Nvidia tactic, including its dishonest approach to reviews that we’ve already detailed in our opinions and its deceptive and, we think, false advertising of the RTX 5070 as being equivalent to an RTX 4090, which is provably and comically false.

Narrator: Following a July 24th publication by the Financial Times reporting that more than a billion dollars of Nvidia AI chips had been smuggled into China, Nvidia downplayed the issue and stated, “Trying to cobble together data centers from smuggled products is a losing proposition, both technically and economically. Data centers require service and support, which we provide only to authorized Nvidia products.” The last part sounds like something a company selling support would say, and the first part doesn’t really match Nvidia’s whole “the more you buy, the more you save” thing. If your only option is a useless, insufficient data center or a cobbled-together sufficient data center, then a cobbled-together one is still a winning proposition by comparison. It’s weird for them to pretend that this isn’t worth doing. It’s worth, like, lots of money.

Narrator: That same day, whitehouse.gov posted an article titled “Why A to Claim for President Trump’s Visionary AI Action Plan.” Near the top of the post, it highlighted a sycophantic quote from Jensen Huang which read, “America’s unique advantage that no country could possibly have is President Trump.” We would call that sycophantic if it’s about any president.

Narrator: On August 5th, the US Department of Justice announced that it had arrested two people in California for smuggling “tens of millions of dollars’ worth of sensitive microchips used in artificial intelligence applications” to China. The court documents say the shipments included the Nvidia H100 and the Nvidia RTX 4090. Rather than admit smuggling exists, Nvidia downplayed the situation again and stated this time, “This case demonstrates that smuggling is a non-starter.” Except that anyone who made tens of millions of dollars before getting caught had a pretty good start—and so did their customers. Nvidia also said, “We primarily sell products to well-known partners, including OEMs, who help us ensure that all sales comply with the US export control rules.” Nvidia noted that “any diverted products would have no service support or updates.” Again, this is not fully true. Our own sources in this story noted that although something like an HGX system would be hard to service, a standalone PCIe GPU could be parted out and covered under a separate warranty, even in China.

Narrator: Meanwhile, the US began scrutinizing Nvidia’s technology for getting into China, whether or not the company itself was directly involved. In a bipartisan report called “DeepSeek Unmasked,” a government committee called DeepSeek a “threat to national security” and said DeepSeek had used Nvidia’s technology. “AI model appears to be powered by advanced chips provided by American semiconductor giant Nvidia and reportedly utilizes tens of thousands of chips that are currently restricted from export to the People’s Republic of China (PRC). NVIDIA designed and manufactured many of these chips to create the most sophisticated possible chip while skirting US export controls. This has allowed these chips to be exported to China as the US government develops stricter restrictions. Since March 2024, it is estimated that Nvidia has produced over 1 million chips for the Chinese market.” The government also examined Nvidia’s significant revenue growth in Singapore compared to China based on SEC filings, particularly in years featuring restrictions. The government questioned “whether PRC customers are arranging for the diversion of sensitive chips that are reportedly sold through Singapore,” stated because revenue from Singapore had grown from almost nothing since 2020 or 2021. Nvidia has defended its sales to Singapore by stating that “customers use Singapore to centralize invoicing while our products are almost always shipped elsewhere.” According to Nvidia, shipments destined to Singapore were only 2% of the company’s total revenue in 2025. But we also know that Singapore has made numerous arrests relating to GPU smuggling, so there appears to be some reason for the concerns whether or not Nvidia itself wants to turn a blind eye to it.

Narrator: Despite the allegations, Nvidia downplayed any smuggling of AI chips. In this video uploaded two months ago from what appears to be either a potato or a VHS tape, Jensen Huang speaks on smuggling.

Jensen Huang: Governments understand that diversion is not allowed. And there’s no evidence of any AI chip diversion.

Narrator: Except that there is evidence of it—not only in this very movie but in readily available reports online for years now.

Jensen Huang: Our data center GPUs are massive. These are massive systems. The Grace Blackwell system is nearly two tons. And so you’re not going to be putting that in your pocket or your backpack anytime soon. And so these systems are fairly easy to keep track of. But the important thing is that the countries and the companies that we sell to recognize that diversion is not allowed and everybody would like to continue to buy Nvidia technology. And so they monitor themselves very carefully and they’re quite careful about that.

Narrator: He’s right in that it is much harder to smuggle Grace Blackwell or Hopper HGX-class systems completely. Dr. Vinci Chow’s statements align with this: “It’s very hard to get a full HGX system.” But it still happens. At least one of Nvidia’s GPU and server customers in another country told us that they facilitate intermediary transmission to China and, in fact, showed us the server racks on site in their facilities. We weren’t allowed to film them, so this footage is from Computex instead, but we saw them. A separate representative told us that document forgery through third-party countries can also disguise such trans-shipments. One middleman told us earlier that an Nvidia distributor gets parts into China. A down-chain factory—not the one we’re showing right now, in case Nvidia has its famed journal of retaliation out—told us that Nvidia’s QC rejects sometimes end up repurposed and kept in China, salvaging the GPU and the VRAM and scrapping the rest. Dr. Vinci Chow told us that one of his own devices had a defective link on it, contributing to this statement because he acquired said device—it just happens to have a defect.

Narrator: In one set of statements, Nvidia says that smuggling doesn’t really happen because the export controls work and keep partners in line. But in another statement, Jensen Huang called the US export controls a “failure,” talking out of both sides of his mouth. He spoke of competing Chinese GPU brands posing a threat to Nvidia: “The local companies are very, very talented and very determined, and the export control gave them the spirit, the energy, and the government support to accelerate their development. I think all in all, the export control was a failure.” The stakes and the dollar signs for Nvidia had increased. Jensen said Nvidia’s market share in China had dropped from 95% to 50%. In Nvidia’s May quarterly earnings—before the H20 exemption and revenue share—Jensen Huang said the company’s data center business in China was done: “However, the $50 billion China market is effectively closed to US industry. The H20 export ban ended our Hopper data center business in China.” Or as Jensen says, the China market is worth one Boeing. “The Chinese market in a couple years is probably about $50 billion. The market we’ve left behind is utterly gigantic. $50 billion—just so you have a feeling for that number. $50 billion is like Boeing.” Probably not the best example, but okay.

Narrator: Let’s look back at the timeline one more time for these export controls on Nvidia, this time highlighting Nvidia’s side of things—its relentless appetite for global domination. The October 7th, 2022 Biden administration export controls had a stated goal of “protecting US national security and foreign policy interests” by implementing new export controls restricting China’s ability to build high-end semiconductors, including for the development of supercomputers. There was an included goal of staving off the potential for China to develop “nuclear weapons and other military technologies.” Blocking the H100 and A100 led to Nvidia creating an export compliant A800 at about 70% of the speed of an A100 for the Chinese market. A year later, on October 17th, 2023, the US Department of Commerce updated its export compliance and restricted Nvidia’s A800 chip as well, alongside the newer China-targeted H800. Weeks later, on December 6th, 2023, Nvidia told reporters in Singapore that it would be working on another new chip that would comply with the US’s new restrictions.

Narrator: On July 13th, 2025, which was after Donald Trump won the 2024 presidential election but a week before he took office, the outgoing Biden administration tightened export controls by introducing national chip caps for many countries except for 18 allies. That’s the AI diffusion rule we spoke of earlier, and it would have gone into effect in May. Nvidia, which had remained relatively quiet about the regulations up until this point, criticized the restriction and made an attempt to appeal to the president-elect: “It makes no sense for the Biden White House to control everyday data center computers and technology that’s already in gaming PCs worldwide, disguised as an anti-China move. The extreme country cap policy will affect mainstream computers in countries around the world, doing nothing to promote national security, but rather pushing the world to alternative technologies. AI is mainstream computing, ubiquitous and essential as electricity. This last-minute Biden administration policy would be a legacy that will be criticized by US industry and the global community.” Nvidia added, “We would encourage President Biden to not preempt incoming President Trump by enacting a policy that will only harm the US economy, set America back, and play into the hands of US adversaries.”

Narrator: This is where in the timeline we’d hit the million-dollar dinner and then the ensuing ban/unban of the H20 chip, but we’ve already covered that. Later that month, on April 30th, Huang said this of Trump: “Without the president’s leadership, his policies, his support, and very importantly his strong encouragement—and I mean strong encouragement—frankly, manufacturing in the United States wouldn’t have accelerated to this pace.”

Narrator: A month after the Mar-a-Lago estate dinner, on May 7th, the US Department of Commerce confirmed that it will not implement the AI diffusion rule that Nvidia campaigned against and that was created under the Biden administration. The rule was supposed to go into effect a week later on May 15th. This does not unban GPUs like the H100, 5090, B100, and so on. Following the termination of what was supposed to be a rule to address national security implications, the Department of Commerce, now under President Trump, stated, “The Biden AI rule is overly complex, overly bureaucratic, and would stymie American innovation. We’ll be replacing it with a much simpler rule that unleashes American innovation and ensures American AI dominance.” Nvidia predictably celebrated this statement and took an America First posture: “We welcome the administration’s leadership and new direction on AI policy. With the AI diffusion rule revoked, America will have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to lead the next industrial revolution and create high-paying US jobs, build new US supply infrastructure, and alleviate the trade deficit.”

Narrator: Later that month, on May 28th, Huang spoke with Mad Money host Jim Cramer:

Jensen Huang: When he rescinded the AI diffusion rule, it was a visionary move. It was a bold move, and he recognizes that there’s an AI race and we’re not alone and he wants America to win.

Narrator: On June 23rd via Reuters, an official of the US State Department warned of DeepSeek military and intelligence operations and warned of the use of shell companies in Southeast Asia to circumvent export restrictions. The report mentioned that DeepSeek had “large volumes” of high-end H100 chips which are banned in China. Nvidia didn’t like that and responded to Reuters, stating, “We do not support parties that have violated US export controls or are on the US entity lists,” also saying, “With the current export controls, we are effectively out of the China data center market, which is now served only by competitors such as Huawei.” Turning a blind eye to the situation, Nvidia added, “Our review indicates that DeepSeek used lawfully acquired H800 products, not H100.” Three days later, on June 26th, The Information reported that DeepSeek’s next AI model had been delayed due to a shortage of Nvidia AI GPUs in China. This directly contradicts Huang’s comments that export controls, according to him, do not work.

Narrator: On July 4th, Bloomberg reported that the Department of Commerce was preparing new export controls on Malaysia and Thailand to reduce chip smuggling. Interestingly, Singapore, which now comprises a significant portion of Nvidia’s revenue, was not on that list despite being a known smuggling pass-through. On July 10th, Bloomberg reported that Huang and Trump were scheduled to meet again ahead of the CEO’s planned trip to China. Days later, on July 14th, Nvidia confirmed that it will resume sales of H20 chips to China with Huang stating, “The US government has assured Nvidia that licenses will be granted, and Nvidia hopes to start delivery soon.” On the 15th, a CNBC business news anchor said this:

Anchor: He really just pulled off something that few tech CEOs have managed. He played both Washington and Beijing and he won. Jensen has stayed disciplined and diplomatic with a clear message, and that is Nvidia’s dominance serves America’s interest.

Narrator: On the 28th, the Financial Times reported that the US Commerce Department was not going to make tough moves to tighten export controls to China. This is in spite of several congressional members warning the administration not to loosen the US export controls for AI GPUs. Several national security experts also voiced concern by sending a letter to the US Commerce Department which read, “We write to express our deep concern over the recent decision to resume exports of Nvidia’s H20 chips to China. As policymakers and professionals with a background in national security policy, we believe this move represents a strategic misstep that endangers the United States’ economic and military edge in artificial intelligence.” On August 11th, we got the comments about the US potentially allowing Blackwell chips to be sold to China as well for 30% to 50% of a revenue share. And that brings us to today.

Narrator: Nvidia might have started off as a much more humble company, but it has become a savvy political player in a game that is seemingly pay-to-win. That seems only fitting for a gaming company to be particularly good at pay-to-win games. There’s no one better equipped to play that game than the most valuable company by market cap in the world, now at $4 trillion, led by a man whose net worth is estimated at $148 billion. Nvidia knows when to bite its tongue and how to effectively appeal to the ego of politicians of all parties and all countries. We think Nvidia is playing all sides. We think it’s greedy, manipulative, and carefully employs propaganda, such as its use of this fake news playbook for news which was literally reality. But we don’t think Nvidia has a particular set of beliefs beyond just making more money. We think Nvidia will sell anybody out to make a buck.

### Signoff: Findings, Methods, and Credits

Narrator: Nvidia is in the big leagues now. It’s not like the 1080 Ti days. Inside of one month, reportedly paying $1 million to a sitting president, after which followed the unlock of five and a half billion dollars of lost H20 revenue, followed next by a 15% split of that unlock going to the US government, is what raises these new questions of Nvidia’s integrity, but we’ve kind of already talked about that over the last year now.

Narrator: As for the actual black market side of things and smuggling, that was a cool story. This was crazy exciting to work on. I loved actually being out in the field and meeting all these people. We set up some of it in advance, but a lot of people we met on the ground there, we were able to actually get to the bottom of something. It’s pretty cool. We’ve learned that common methods include factory so-called QC “defects,” or sometimes real ones, where they repurpose hardware that might otherwise have been written off by—especially—Nvidia as just trash, but people with the right skills can reclaim it. We learned about the other method of hand-carrying items, like with students, or actual smugglers on the ground in the US facilitating the transfer of the GPUs. And of course, we learned about suppliers through third-party countries, among other methods. So we did answer the question that we had going into this, which was all about how these cards get in. Again, we loved working on this story and meeting all of these unique people. Each person played a key role in helping us find the next person and allowing us to complete the first public on-record start-to-finish cataloging of a smuggling pipeline for high-end silicon. Our sincere thanks to everybody who made this possible and appeared on camera with us, including our viewers who funded it.

Narrator: And a big thanks to my team working on this project. Vitali, Andrew, and Mike spent about a month training Tannon how to use a camera because we needed a camera operator for this trip and he’s a writer. Vitali helmed the overall production organization of the files and cutting of the 12 hours of footage initially. Andrew led the artistic efforts, worked on the new products, did the great scene transitions you saw, and general graphics. Tannon was on the camera and worked with me in Asia for three weeks on the story and during a lot of travel. Tim on the team handled the bulk editing of the informational sections and the timeline for this video. And Ben compiled hundreds of pages of research and worked directly with me throughout the process to figure out what the hell this story was going to be. A thanks to Ryan for doing the Black Market logo as well, and all the other contributions in between, like from Aaron Pauly and Matthew Kachihifi on some of the music contributions.

Narrator: Thanks for watching. Subscribe for more. We have more of these in the works. You can go to store.gamersnexus.net to support this directly. Thank you.

parts:
# GamersNexus’ GPU-smuggling investigation — findings & implications

## What GN actually found (on-the-ground evidence)
- **A functioning gray/black market pipeline exists** that moves high-end Nvidia GPUs into mainland China despite US export controls. GN mapped roles along the chain (“source → plug → mule → middleman/warehouse → fence → fixer → user”) and documented each link with interviews and field visits across Hong Kong, Shenzhen/Huaqiangbei (SEG Market), Taiwan, Singapore, and the US. fileciteturn0file0  
- **Retail visibility in Hong Kong**: banned gaming GPUs (e.g., RTX 5090/4090) were openly offered in shops as “parallel imports,” with price premiums but ready availability; supply commonly traced to Australia/Thailand/Taiwan and student hand-carry.  
- **Warehousing in Shenzhen’s orbit**: GN filmed floors of small “upstairs” warehouses feeding the markets with cartons of GPUs; traders emphasized **piecemeal ingress (“ants moving house”)** rather than bulk shipments.  
- **Intermediary pass-throughs**: B2B firms in **Singapore and Taiwan** pre-assemble or “test” systems containing export-controlled accelerators before re-shipping to final Chinese buyers.  
- **A US link (“The Plug”)**: a US-based buyer drives city-to-city offering flat rates (~$2,000) for RTX 4090s, testing in a car rig and exporting PCBs/coolers separately to improve margins; reported profits are thin (~$300/card before costs) but scale accrues.  
- **Factory leakage & QC salvage**: because **assembly of many Nvidia boards occurs in China**, GN’s sources described “falling off the line” scenarios and **QC-reject repurposing**; serializable silicon and VRAM are salvaged while PCBs/VRMs are replaced.  
- **Aftermarket “fixers” upgrade cards for AI**: GN filmed a shop that routinely **converts RTX 4090s from 24 GB to 48 GB** on custom PCBs via reballing—creating SKUs Nvidia doesn’t offer but that are attractive for LLM fine-tuning.  
- **University demand & constraints**: Hong Kong researchers reported **VRAM capacity** (not raw FLOPS) as the gating metric, finding H20 (96 GB) attractive; export controls hinder **very large-scale clusters** but not small/medium research use.  
- **Policy mechanics are leaky and whipsawing**: GN walks through **TPP/perf-density thresholds**, later **opaque memory-bandwidth caps**, rescinded “diffusion” proposals, and the **limited license/revenue-share carve-out** for H20/MI308—highlighting how vendors tune SKUs around shifting rules.  
- **Corporate stance**: GN characterizes Nvidia as “turning a blind eye,” juxtaposing the company’s public minimization of diversion with evidence of smuggling arrests and visible gray-market activity; GN frames this as incentive-aligned behavior under massive revenue pressure.

## What it means (my assessment)

### 1) Export controls constrain **scale**, not **access**
- **Efficacy:** The controls appear effective at **preventing super-scale (e.g., 10k–100k GPU) clusters** by raising coordination risk, warranty gaps, and logistics frictions for full HGX racks.  
- **Inefficacy:** They do **not** prevent **retail-through-meso-scale access**. Ant-trail logistics, student hand-carry, modular shipments (PCBs/coolers split), and third-country pass-throughs deliver a steady trickle sufficient for labs, SMEs, and provincial data centers.

**Net effect:** China’s **peak compute** is slowed; its **broad access** is not. That is a partial strategic success, not a blockade.

### 2) Policy design choices inadvertently **privilege VRAM-heavy, lower-FLOPS** parts
- FLOPS-oriented thresholds (later tweaked) pushed vendors toward **H20-style** specs: **lower tensor throughput, very high VRAM**—exactly what LLM fine-tuning/inference needs in multi-GPU topologies.  
- Opaque bandwidth caps add uncertainty, but **capacity is king** for many workloads; consequently, **smuggling + aftermarket VRAM doubling** blunt the intended performance ceilings by substituting memory for raw TOPS.

**Net effect:** Rules aimed at “speed” leave a hole for **capacity-driven AI** use; expect further rule iterations to target **HBM capacity**, **IO fabric**, and **attestation-gated firmware** rather than FLOPS alone.

### 3) Controls catalyze **domestic substitution & ecosystem hardening**
- By making Nvidia unreliable for sovereign planning, controls **accelerate** Huawei/others and sustain a **repair/mod industry** that lengthens asset lifetimes and increases self-reliance.  
- CUDA moat persists short-term, but **PyTorch ROCm**, **OpenXLA**, and **framework portability** efforts gain policy tailwinds when access to CUDA is politicized.

**Net effect:** Short-run frictions; **medium-term diversification** with still-material performance gaps vs. Nvidia.

### 4) Corporate/governance risk
- GN’s reporting strengthens the case for **tighter serial-level provenance**, **export attestation**, **RMA/warranty gating by region & chain-of-custody**, and **transshipment enforcement** (esp. for HK, SG, MY, TH).  
- Nvidia faces **reputational and regulatory pressure** if legislators treat “blind eye” narratives as credible; expect more **entity-list expansions** and **compliance audits** of distributors and SI partners.

**Net effect:** Vendors likely move to **cryptographically enforced device activation**, per-region firmware, or **data-center attestation** (with real costs and collateral damage for legitimate refurb/repair).

### 5) Market/pricing
- The investigation shows Hong Kong retail **price premiums but not scarcity**—implying **elastic gray-market supply**.  
- Smugglers’ **thin margins** mean the trade is **volume-sensitive** and **enforcement-sensitive**—small crackdowns raise risk cost and can whipsaw availability.

**Net effect:** Expect **periodic volatility** rather than persistent droughts.

## Strengths & limits of GN’s work (objectivity check)

**Strengths**
- **Direct evidence chain** from US buyer → HK/China traders & warehouses → mainland fixer → institutional users.  
- **Method triangulation**: filmed purchases, price quotes, physical warehouses, factory context, and university cluster ops—rare in tech reporting.

**Limitations / caveats**
- Some claims (e.g., factory “fall-off-the-line”) rely on **anonymized sources** and are **inherently hard to quantify**.  
- **Selection bias**: Shenzhen/HK markets are outliers in visibility; findings may **overrepresent** availability relative to other regions.  
- **Causality vs. correlation** in the political timeline: GN’s “playing all sides/corruption” frame is **editorial**; the factual substrate (policy whiplash; carve-outs) is real, but motive inference remains **contestable**.  
- **Performance claims** for modified cards (e.g., 48 GB 4090) aren’t benchmarked here; **stability, yield, thermals, and ECC absence** matter for production AI.

## Forward look — what changes next
- **Enforcement migrates to the edges**: expect **more transshipment arrests**, **controlled-goods audits** in HK/SG/MY/TH, and closer **parcel analytics** for “parts-only” shipments.  
- **Device-level controls**: **activation servers**, **CC-mode + attestation** as preconditions for driver updates/warranty, and **RMA segregation** by jurisdiction.  
- **Metric shift**: regulators pivot from FLOPS to **VRAM/HBM capacity, interconnect bandwidth (NVLink/PCIe-Gen5/6, IB-NDR/XDR)** and **rack-level caps**.  
- **Ecosystem response**: more **ROCm/Ascend** maturation; **LLM pipelines** optimized for **memory-frugal training (LoRA, MoE, 4/8-bit)** to fit within permitted SKUs.  
- **Repair/mod formalization vs. crackdown**: either tacit tolerance as a circular-economy valve or tighter **custom-PCB/BIOS** controls and **marketplace policing**.

## Bottom line
GN convincingly demonstrates that **smuggling and gray-market diversion are real, routine, and structurally embedded**, and that **US export controls have shifted from “deny access” to “dampen scale.”** The investigation also shows how **market incentives (VRAM-first AI), policy instability, and globalized assembly** create durable leakage paths that are hard to close without **device-level attestation and transshipment enforcement**—both of which carry costs for legitimate users and refurbishers. The piece’s **hard findings** (pipeline, availability, aftermarket upgrades, intermediaries) are strong; its **normative claims** about Nvidia’s intent are plausible but **not dispositive**, and will likely be litigated in policy and press rather than in court.
